body:
Failing at import is not very tantric. Do we have tests?

On Wed, 17 Apr 2019, 12:23 José Jiménez, <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> In [2]: from moleculekit.smallmol.smallmol import SmallMol
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
> AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
> <ipython-input-2-26fcfa8998d6> in <module>()
> ----> 1 from moleculekit.smallmol.smallmol import SmallMol
>
> /shared/jose/moleculekit/moleculekit/smallmol/smallmol.py in <module>()
>      29
>      30 _hybridizations_IdxToType = HybridizationType.values
> ---> 31 _hybridizations_StringToType = {'S': HybridizationType.S,
>      32                                 'SP': HybridizationType.SP,
>      33                                 'SP2': HybridizationType.SP2,
>
> AttributeError: type object 'HybridizationType' has no attribute 'S'
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/Acellera/moleculekit/issues/3>, or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AHaqOmu1qiR6BqfHNg-1pmlOznSTi3s4ks5vhwQ4gaJpZM4c00aq>
> .
>

We have 72% code test coverage. More than any other project we have written. It's just that I decided that I hate rdkit so it's not in the dependencies. You need to install it yourself. Still the error is...weird... 
Are you sure you have rdkit installed Jose?
I will try to add a nicer error for the missing import. I wonder how it doesn't error directly on the rdkit import

I do.

```
In [1]: from moleculekit.smallmol.smallmol import SmallMol
/shared/jose/conda/lib/python3.6/site-packages/rdkit/Chem/PeriodicTable.py:131: FutureWarning: split() requires a non-empty pattern match.
  splitLine = blankExpr.split(line)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-1-26fcfa8998d6> in <module>()
----> 1 from moleculekit.smallmol.smallmol import SmallMol

/shared/jose/moleculekit/moleculekit/smallmol/smallmol.py in <module>()
     29 
     30 _hybridizations_IdxToType = HybridizationType.values
---> 31 _hybridizations_StringToType = {'S': HybridizationType.S,
     32                                 'SP': HybridizationType.SP,
     33                                 'SP2': HybridizationType.SP2,

AttributeError: type object 'HybridizationType' has no attribute 'S'

In [2]: import rdkit

In [3]: 
```


The latest htmdmol does not crash with this.
Can be the rdkit version?

Actually @cuzzo87 might have a point. I have an old rdkit version in this env.

```
In [3]: rdkit.__version__
Out[3]: '2015.09.1'
```

Let me try updating it.
ah ok then the issue is obvious. Update to the acellera one though! not the official rdkit one
Ok if you all want I will add rdkit to the deps so that it's version-fixed.

oh it's actually my fault. For some reason after activating the environment conda was still looking at the packages from the base env.

Sneaky conda.

> Ok if you all want I will add rdkit to the deps so that it's version-fixed.

the official one from the rdkit channel works just fine. No need.
Nononono! It's bad.
Ok you convinced me to version-lock rdkit to moleculekit. Otherwise people will do this thinking they are clever and hit themselves in the face.

For reference, this one works just fine:

```
In [2]: rdkit.__version__                                                                                                                                                                    
Out[2]: '2018.09.2'
```
You think it works fine. That's what I'm telling you. The fact that it doesn't error does not mean it's not full of bugs.
Bugs which affect the results and don't cause errors.
@hawk31 the version of 2018 is going to fail with some code in the util, like `from rdkit.Chem import ChemicalFeatures`
Also it will generate really bad coordinates for molecules

So far I'm just cloning `moleculekit` and exporting it to my `PYTHONPATH`.

Is the expected user behaviour to execute `pip install -e .` ?

Conda or pip-install it from pypi or anaconda I'd say. Installing from the
repo is not very clean because I had to do a hack for the dependencies

On Wed, Apr 17, 2019 at 2:58 PM José Jiménez <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> So far I'm just cloning moleculekit and exporting it to my PYTHONPATH.
>
> Is the expected user behaviour to execute pip install -e . ?
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/Acellera/moleculekit/issues/3#issuecomment-484053025>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AHkVgkO4aC-yTqVG03iUJcdM3xNBXAwGks5vhwx-gaJpZM4c00aq>
> .
>

After removing `rdkit` from the environment, `conda install -c acellera moleculekit`  does not retrieve any rdkit dependency, though:

```
(dockbench) [jose@workspace3 ~]$ conda install -c acellera moleculekit
Fetching package metadata ...............
Solving package specifications: .

Package plan for installation in environment /shared/jose/conda/envs/dockbench:

The following NEW packages will be INSTALLED:

    moleculekit: 0.1.6-py36h39e3cac_0 acellera

Proceed ([y]/n)? 
```
Read above messages please :)

yes because it is not a dependency, You should install it like this:

`conda install -c acellera rdkit`

> Ok if you all want I will add rdkit to the deps so that it's version-fixed.

I am confused.



> yes because it is not a dependency, You should install it like this:
> 
> `conda install -c acellera rdkit`

I am more confused.

So do I install the dependency manually, or will it be added to a deps file eventually?
Do you want to wait until it's added to the deps? :P

repository.name: moleculekit
repository.description: MoleculeKit: Your favorite molecule manipulation kit
